title: Blackwood Forest Walks and MTB

images.title: Glyn Baker / Black Wood
images.caption: Black Wood. This is a forest track in a large wood managed by the Forestry Commission

images.title: Graham Horn / Junction in Black Wood
images.caption: Junction in Black Wood. The wood is open access land and is a maze of tracks. Fortunately if you get lost keep going in the same direction and within one kilometre you will reach the edge of the wood.  It is not dense woodland, and comprises mainly natural species such as beech and birch.

images.title: Graham Horn / Roe Deer in Black Wood
images.caption: Roe Deer in Black Wood. This was one of a pair of Roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), as they are usually found; the other is off to the right behind a tree. But unusually, they did not bolt immediately. We stared at each other for quite a while, sufficiently long for me to get out my camera. The wood is an ancient woodland, part of Micheldever Forest, managed by the Forestry Commission to a 30 year plan.

images.title: Glyn Baker / Clearing in Black Wood
images.caption: Clearing in Black Wood. This area of the wood has been clear of trees for at least 50 years.

images.title: Diane Sambrook / Bridleway near Bradley Farm
images.caption: Bridleway near Bradley Farm at the southern end of the woods, near the adjacent Stratton Park and Embley Wood.

images.title: Glyn Baker / Black Wood
images.caption: One of the entrance paths to Black Wood at the southern end of the site. Forestry Commission sign also pictured here.

description: This forested area is located a few miles south west of Basingstoke and not far from Winchester. There's a number of good walking and cycling trails to try in the 270-hectare beech woods. It's also the home of Forest Holidays where you can hire a log cabin and stay over in the woods. The site includes a centre where you can hire mountain bikes or enjoy a meal in the cafe. You can start your exercise from the centre where there's parking available at postcode SO21 3BG for your sat navs. If you are coming by public transport then Micheldever train station is located just to the west of the forest. Other highlights in the forest include various woodland birds and pretty bluebells in the spring.
